newsitem.title: USA: US FCC grants first airwave license to Teledesic. [CORRECTED 09:12 GMT 15/3]
newsitem.headline: US FCC grants first airwave license to Teledesic. [CORRECTED 09:12 GMT 15/3]

text.p: The U.S. Federal Communications Commission on Friday licensed a company backed by Microsoft Corp and Craig McCaw (corrects from "McCaw Cellular") to offer telephone and Internet services over the airwaves.

The license authorizes Teledesic to build, launch and operate a satellite system in non-geostationary satellite orbit to provide domestic and international fixed-satellite services on the so-called Ka-band, the FCC said.
This is the first such license the FCC has granted.
Seattle-based Teledesic is backed by former McCaw Cellular Chairman Craig McCaw and Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates. (Corrects to show that Craig McCaw is no longer connected to McCaw Cellular)
"Teledesic proposes an innovative satellite constellation that will comprise an 'Internet in the sky,'" the FCC said in a statement.

The satellite system will link computers around the world with high-speed connections. The Teledesic network will also offer channels for voice, videoconferencing, interactive multimedia and real-time, two-way digital data, the FCC said.
